message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the patient, such as being talkative, disorganized, and easily distracted, suggest attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). The fact that the patient scored 95 on an IQ test indicates that he does not have intellectual disability. Dyslexia and persistent depressive disorder do not fit with the symptoms reported. The patient's ability to read the age-appropriate children’s book fluently and correctly suggests he does not have dyslexia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as being talkative, disorganized, easily distracted, and having difficulty completing tasks, suggest attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Dyslexia would manifest as difficulty reading, which is not the case for this patient. Persistent depressive disorder and intellectual disability are unlikely based on the patient’s normal physical examination and IQ test results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. Dyslexia primarily affects reading ability, and the patient is able to read fluently and correctly. Persistent depressive disorder is unlikely given the absence of symptoms such as sadness, loss of interest, or low self-esteem. Intellectual disability is also unlikely given the normal IQ test results and meeting developmental milestones on time.

This is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, which can lead to poor academic performance. The normal physical examination, normal IQ test score, and ability to read age-appropriate children’s books fluently and correctly make dyslexia and intellectual disability less likely. Persistent depressive disorder is not likely given the absence of symptoms such as sadness and loss of interest in activities.
